questions.text:
A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of nasal congestion and fatigue for 12 days. During this period, he has had a fever and severe pain around his cheeks. His nasal discharge was initially clear but it has turned yellowish over the past couple of days. He has no visual complaints. He has been taking an over-the-counter nasal decongestant and acetaminophen without much relief. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He underwent an appendectomy 23 years ago. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and enalapril. He appears tired. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. Examination shows purulent discharge in the nose and pharynx and normal-appearing ears. The left maxillary sinus is tender to palpation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
10,800/mm3



Platelet count
263,000/mm3



ESR
22 mm/hr


Serum



 Glucose
112 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the paranasal sinuses

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the sinuses would most likely show sinus opacity and air-fluid levels in a patient with bacterial sinusitis. However, x-rays of the sinuses are usually not recommended in acute sinusitis because the results do not help to differentiate between etiologies and rarely influence the choice of treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent used to treat and prevent severe fungal infections such as aspergillosis, candidiasis, coccidioidomycosis, mucormycosis, and histoplasmosis. Fungal sinusitis (e.g., caused by Aspergillus species) is rare and usually only occurs in immunocompromised patients. Although diabetes mellitus is a risk factor, there is no indication that his diabetes is poorly controlled, making this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, fungal sinusitis due to Aspergillus is usually accompanied by asthma and other atopic manifestations. A different treatment is more appropriate at this time.

C) CORRECT:

Acute bacterial rhinosinusitis can develop following AVRS and is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae or Haemophilus influenzae. Amoxicillin/clavulanic acid is a penicillin antibiotic combined with a β-lactamase inhibitor that is used to treat a number of bacterial infections, particularly respiratory tract infections. This antibiotic is considered the first-line treatment for acute bacterial rhinosinusitis and, therefore, initiation of amoxicillin/clavulanic acid is the most appropriate next step for this patient.

A third-generation cephalosporin (with or without clindamycin, doxycycline), a respiratory fluoroquinolone, or a macrolide can be used to treat patients with a penicillin allergy. In addition to antibiotic treatment, the patient should receive antipyretic and analgesic therapy and be advised to rest and drink sufficient amounts of fluid.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan would most likely show soft tissue swelling, mucoperiosteal thickening, and air-fluid levels in a patient with bacterial sinusitis. However, a CT scan of the paranasal sinuses is not routinely performed in acute sinusitis. A CT scan may be performed if complications occur (e.g., osteomyelitis, orbital cellulitis) to rule out differential diagnoses (e.g., neoplasms), and preoperatively in patients with chronic sinusitis (e.g., before surgical debridement of necrotic tissue and/or removal of anatomical obstructions).
Image Description:

CT paranasal sinuses (coronal plane) of a patient with acute sinusitis

The right maxillary sinus (green overlay) is completely opacified. Extensive soft tissue density material (red overlay) is also present in the ipsilateral nasal cavity and the right ethmoid sinus is nearly completely opacified.

E) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections, including respiratory tract infections and urinary tract infections. However, this medication is considered a second-line antibiotic in the treatment of acute bacterial sinusitis. Treatment with a second-line antibiotic (e.g., levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, cefuroxime, clindamycin) is indicated in patients who fail to respond to first-line therapy within 72 hours, have symptoms that persist more than two weeks after the initiation of therapy, or that may have been exposed to highly resistant organisms.

F) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and supportive treatment with antipyretics, analgesics, and nasal decongestants are usually sufficient in the treatment of patients with viral rhinosinusitis. However, because this patient has had symptoms for more than 10 days and a mucopurulent discharge suggestive of a bacterial infection, a different treatment is indicated.
questions.hint: This patient's initial symptoms (watery nasal discharge, fever, headache, and facial pain) are consistent with acute viral rhinosinusitis (AVRS). AVRS usually resolves within 7–10 days; however, the development of mucopurulent discharge with a clinical course greater than 10 days is highly suggestive of bacterial superinfection.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of severe pain and swelling of her right eye for 3 days. Over the past 2 weeks, she has had nasal congestion and a constant, mild headache. She did not visit a doctor and instead took over-the-counter naproxen and phenylephrine. Her nasal congestion has since improved, but the headache persists. She underwent a dental procedure for caries about 10 days ago. She does not recollect any recent insect bites or trauma. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears ill and reports occasional chills. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows proptosis of the right eye. Vision is impaired in the affected eye. Her right upper and lower eyelids are erythematous, swollen, and tender to touch. Ocular movements cause severe pain. Her headache is worsened by leaning forward and improves when the patient is lying on her back. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis leads to proptosis and swelling of the conjunctiva. However, cavernous sinus thrombosis also manifests with symptoms related to the damage caused to structures that pass through the sinus, such as the cranial nerves responsible for eye movement (oculomotor, CN III; trochlear, CN IV; abducens, CN VI) and the ophthalmic and maxillary branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). This leads to ophthalmoplegia and loss of sensation in the upper two-thirds of the face. Since this patient does not have any cranial nerve symptoms, cavernous sinus thrombosis is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients who have recently undergone a dental procedure are at risk of developing a dental abscess, which can spread to the orbit and cause orbital cellulitis. However, dental abscesses typically manifest with pain and swelling in the area of the abscess and systemic symptoms, such as fever, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty swallowing and/or speaking. This patient does not have any symptoms that indicate a tooth infection or dental abscess; therefore, her symptoms are likely due to a different underlying disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Rarely, dacryocystitis can spread to adjacent areas, causing orbital cellulitis. However, this patient does not have a history of dacryocystitis and typical clinical features (e.g., localized tenderness in medial canthal region, epiphora, purulent discharge from the punctum) are absent; therefore, her symptoms are likely due to a different underlying disorder.
Image Description:

Right eye of a 54-year-old male patient

A solid and immobile mass can be seen in the right fossa lacrimalis. There is no discharge of pus or other secretions.

These findings are typical of dacryocystitis, which can result from chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac and/or chronic stenosis of the tear duct.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient may have initially had viral sinusitis. However, the persistence of this patient's symptoms for two weeks makes it more likely that she now has bacterial sinusitis. In addition, orbital cellulitis is typically due to bacterial rather than viral pathogens. Lastly, the sphenoid sinuses are located in the sphenoid bones near the optic nerve and pituitary gland. Therefore, spread to the orbit from a sphenoid sinus would be less likely than spread from a sinus that is closer to the orbits.

E) INCORRECT:

Orbital mucormycosis may occur due to fungal spread in patients with ethmoid or maxillary fungal sinusitis. Patients with fungal sinusitis typically have either poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, HIV, or a history of long-term steroid therapy, and are usually immunocompromised. These patients would present with palatal or nasal mucosal ulceration in addition to the other signs and symptoms of sinusitis. Since this patient is young, healthy, and is not immunocompromised, a fungal source of infection is unlikely.

F) CORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis is most commonly caused by bacterial spread from ethmoidal or maxillary sinusitis, as these sinuses are most proximal to the orbits. This patient's history of recent sinusitis makes bacterial spread from the ethmoidal sinus the most likely cause of her symptoms. Sinusitis can cause orbital or preseptal (anterior to the orbital septum) cellulitis. Orbital cellulitis can be distinguished from preseptal cellulitis by the presence of pain with ocular movements and vision changes.
Image Description:

The left upper and lower eyelids are red and severely swollen, resulting in the patient not being able to open the eye. Orbital cellulitis is an emergency requiring immediate treatment.
questions.hint: This girl has impaired vision (likely due to diplopia), proptosis, eyelid erythema and tenderness, and severe pain on ocular movement, which is indicative of orbital cellulitis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of double vision and rapidly worsening pain and swelling of her right eye. For the past week, she has had nasal congestion, recurrent headaches, and a watery nasal discharge that became purulent 4 days ago. She started antibiotics for these symptoms but did not complete the course. She has asthma treated with theophylline and inhaled β-adrenergic agonists and corticosteroids. She appears to be in severe distress. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination of the right eye shows proptosis and diffuse edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelids. Right eye movements are restricted and painful in all directions. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is tenderness to palpation over the right cheek and purulent nasal discharge in the right nasal cavity. The left eye shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,000/mm3. Which of the following provides the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics to this patient?

choices.text: Edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelid
Purulent nasal discharge and right cheek tenderness

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Worsening ocular pain can be caused by a number of ophthalmic conditions, such as corneal abrasions, angle-close glaucoma, endophthalmitis, preseptal cellulitis, and orbital cellulitis. Therefore, ocular pain is a non-specific symptom that, as a sole clinical feature, is not an indication for the initiation of IV antibiotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Unilateral diffuse edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelid can occur in any condition that causes ocular infection or inflammation, e.g. blepharitis, bacterial conjunctivitis, endophthalmitis, preseptal cellulitis, and orbital cellulitis. Therefore, diffuse inflammation of the eyelid as a sole clinical feature is non-specific and not an indication to initiate IV antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Leukocytosis is a nonspecific symptom of many conditions, including viral infections or inflammatory conditions, some of which do not require antibiotic treatment at all. In this case, the patient's leukocytosis could be a sign of sinusitis or preseptal cellulitis. Bacterial sinusitis and mild preseptal cellulitis can be managed with oral antibiotics. Because both orbital cellulitis and preseptal cellulitis manifest with fever, leukocytosis, and acute ocular pain and inflammation, usually in conjunction with acute rhinosinusitis, it is important to identify specific findings of orbital cellulitis, which always requires IV antibiotics.

D) CORRECT:

Rapidly progressive pain with eye movements is a sign of inflammation of the orbital content. While fever, leukocytosis, and eyelid changes (e.g., edema, erythema, tenderness) can occur with both preseptal cellulitis and orbital cellulitis, painful ocular movements, ophthalmoplegia, reduced vision, and proptosis are specific for orbital cellulitis, a sight-threatening infection of the orbital contents. While preseptal cellulitis can be treated with oral antibiotics, the spread of infection to the orbital tissues requires prompt treatment with empiric IV antibiotics (vancomycin plus one of the following: ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, ampicillin/sulbactam, piperacillin/tazobactam).

See “Orbital cellulitis vs. preseptal cellulitis” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Purulent discharge in the right nasal cavity, right cheek tenderness, and a recent history of headaches and nasal congestion are characteristic of right maxillary sinusitis. Bacterial sinusitis is the most likely etiological factor of this patient's orbital cellulitis. However, oral (not parenteral) antibiotics alone would be appropriate to treat bacterial sinusitis.

F) INCORRECT:

Fever is a nonspecific symptom of many conditions, including viral infections or inflammatory conditions, some of which do not require antibiotic treatment at all. In this case, the patient's fever could be a sign of sinusitis or preseptal cellulitis. Bacterial sinusitis and mild preseptal cellulitis can be managed with oral antibiotics. Because both orbital cellulitis and preseptal cellulitis manifest with fever and acute ocular pain and inflammation, usually in conjunction with acute rhinosinusitis, it is important to identify specific findings of orbital cellulitis, which always requires IV antibiotics.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features consistent with right-sided orbital cellulitis. Her recent episode of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis (as evidenced by nasal congestion, headaches, cheek tenderness, and purulent nasal discharge) is the most likely primary source of infection.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man with asthma comes to the office because of a 5-week history of nasal congestion, watery nasal discharge, and frequent headaches. During this time, he noticed increased mouth breathing and his wife told him that he started snoring. He has also had several episodes of a dry cough that have kept him awake at night. One year ago, he had an asthma exacerbation while being treated for an ankle sprain. Two weeks ago, he had another asthma exacerbation after taking ibuprofen for his headaches. Current medications are a combined budesonide-formoterol inhaler and an over-the-counter nasal decongestant. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild tenderness over the forehead bilaterally. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma also manifests with symptoms of nasal obstruction and nasal discharge. However, patients with this condition most commonly present with recurrent severe epistaxis, which is not seen here. Moreover, this condition is almost exclusively seen in adolescent males.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the inside of the right nasal cavity of a young patient

A large smooth and vascular mass is obstructing the entire nasal cavity.

This is the typical appearance of a nasal angiofibroma.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with AERD, which commonly manifests with the Samter triad: asthma, chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, and hypersensitivity to aspirin or other cyclooxygenase-1 inhibitors. Patients with nasal polyps typically present with symptoms of postnasal drip (e.g., dry cough when lying supine) and nasal obstruction (e.g., mouth breathing, new-onset snoring). Diagnosis is confirmed by nasal endoscopy; in cases of unilateral nasal polyps, a biopsy is performed to exclude malignancy. A CT scan can be performed to exclude other causes of nasal obstruction. Nasal polyps can also be seen in individuals with chronic rhinosinusitis, even in the absence of asthma or aspirin sensitivity.

Intranasal corticosteroids are the first-line therapy for nasal polyposis. In patients who do not respond to topical steroids, other treatments might be indicated (e.g., systemic steroids, monoclonal antibodies, surgery). Aspirin desensitization may also be performed in patients with AERD.
Image Description:

CT paranasal sinuses (without contrast; coronal plane) of patient with history of asthma

Extensive soft tissue opacification of the ethmoid sinuses (E; outline) and nasal cavity (NC; outline) shows some lobulation (black arrowhead) and evidence of bony erosion (dashed outline). Lobulated soft tissue is also present along the maxillary sinus walls (white arrowheads).

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic vasculitis such as ANCA-associated vasculitis (e.g., eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) can manifest with nasal congestion, nasal discharge, and cough. Moreover, patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis typically present with asthma. However, since ANCA-associated vasculitis usually affects multiple organ systems, patients typically have concomitant findings suggestive of multi-organ involvement (e.g., glomerulonephritis, skin manifestations, pulmonary symptoms), which are not seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Bacterial rhinosinusitis manifests with nasal discharge, congestion, postnasal drip, headache, and facial tenderness, all of which are seen in this patient. However, patients with bacterial rhinosinusitis typically present with more severe symptoms such as fever and thick, purulent nasal discharge, rather than watery discharge. This patient's history of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease makes a different diagnosis much more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Intranasal foreign bodies can cause symptoms of nasal obstruction and nasal discharge, as seen here. However, the nasal obstruction and discharge caused by intranasal foreign bodies is typically mucopurulent rather than watery. Moreover, intranasal foreign bodies are most commonly seen in children.

F) INCORRECT:

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) can manifest with nasal discharge and nasal congestion, as seen here. However, patients with NPC usually present with bloody rather than watery nasal discharge. Moreover, this condition is more commonly seen in older individuals (peak incidence 50-59 years of age), and this patient has no known risk factors for it (e.g., tobacco consumption, alcohol use).
questions.hint: This patient's history of asthma exacerbations after taking NSAIDs is highly suggestive of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD).

questions.text: A healthy 29-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for genetic counseling prior to conception. Her brother has a disease that has resulted in infertility, a right-sided heart, and frequent sinus and ear infections. No other family members are affected. The intended father's family history of this disease is unknown and he is asymptomatic. The population prevalence of this disease is 1 in 40,000. Which of the following best represents the chance that this patient’s offspring will develop her brother's disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

0.7% is an incorrect answer that might be selected because of a calculation error. The chance of having an affected offspring = (probability of each parent passing on the affected gene) * (probability that each patient is a carrier). For this case, if one does not take into account the 50% chance that each potential heterozygote parent has of passing on the affected gene, they would incorrectly arrive at the answer of 0.7%.

B) INCORRECT:

The probability of the patient's partner being a heterozygous carrier for Kartagener syndrome is 1%. This is not, however, the chance that the patient's offspring will develop the disease. Using the Hardy-Weinberg principle, if the population prevalence (q2) is 1/40,000, then the diseased allele frequency (q) is √(1/40,000) = 1/200. The normal allele frequency (p) = 1-(diseased allele frequency) = 1-q = 1-(1/200) = 199/200. The chance of the patient's partner being a heterozygous carrier is 2pq = 2*(199/200)*(1/200) = 199/20,000 = .00995*100 = 0.995% ≈ 1%.

C) INCORRECT:

If there was 100% certainty that the patient and the father were both heterozygote carriers for Kartagener syndrome, then the chance that this patient’s offspring would develop the disease would be 25%, because both parents would have a 50% chance of passing on the affected gene. The chance of having an affected offspring = (probability of each parent passing on the affected gene) * (probability that each patient is a carrier): (1/2)(1) * (1/2)(1) = 25%. Note that 25% is actually the probability of this patient's parents having an offspring with the disease; this is not the chance that the patient's offspring will develop the disease.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient's chance that she is a healthy heterozygous carrier of Kartagener syndrome is 66%, but this is not the chance that the patient's offspring will develop the disease. Since this patient does not have the disease, she cannot carry two recessive traits. Therefore, she has a ⅔ chance (66%) of being a carrier and a ⅓ chance (33%) of not inheriting the mutation.

E) INCORRECT:

Using the Hardy-Weinberg principle, if the population prevalence (q2) is 1/40,000, then the diseased allele frequency (q) is √(1/40,000) = 1/200 = 0.005*100 = 0.5%. The diseased allele frequency is the probability of someone carrying the allele, which is not equivalent to the probability of the patient's offspring developing Kartagener syndrome (i.e., being homozygous).

F) CORRECT:

In an autosomal recessive disease, an offspring of two heterozygote parents has a ½ chance of being a carrier of the mutation (heterozygote), a ¼ chance of having the disease, and a ¼ chance of not inheriting the mutation at all. Since this patient does not have the disease, she cannot carry two recessive traits. Therefore, she has a ⅔ chance of being a carrier (½ / ¾), and a ⅓ chance of not having inherited the mutation.

For the patient's partner, the genotype of the parents is unknown, and the heterozygote frequency is calculated by using the Hardy-Weinberg law: (p+q)2 = p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1, where 2pq is the chance of being a heterozygous carrier, p2 is the homozygote frequency of the normal allele, and q2 is the homozygote frequency of the diseased allele (i.e., the population prevalence). If the population prevalence (q2) is 1/40,000, then the diseased allele frequency (q) = √(1/40,000) = 1/200. The normal allele frequency (p) = 1-(diseased allele frequency) = 1-q = 1-(1/200) = 199/200. Therefore, the partner's chance of being a heterozygous carrier is 2pq = 2*(199/200)*(1/200) = 2*199/40,000 = 199/20,000 = .00995.

To determine the probability of the child inheriting the affected allele from the mother AND from the father (i.e., having the disease in an autosomal recessive disease), the probabilities of each parent being a heterozygous carrier AND passing on that allele have to be multiplied by each other according to the multiplication rule (conditional probability). The probability of a heterozygote carrier passing on an affected allele is 50%. Therefore, the calculation would be (1/2)(2/3) * (1/2)(199/20,000) = 0.0017 = ∼ 0.2% in this case.

To simplify the calculation, consider rounding (p) up from 199/200 to 1. The partner's chance of being a heterozygous carrier can be solved with the following equation: 2pq = 2*(1)*(1/200) = 2/200 = 1/100. Thereafter, the final calculation is (1/2)(2/3) * (1/2)(1/100) = ∼ 0.2%
questions.hint: The combination of infertility, a right-sided heart, and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections is consistent with Kartagener syndrome, which is an autosomal recessive condition. The probability of the offspring developing the condition (i.e., being homozygous) depends on the probability of the parents being heterozygous AND passing on the affected allele. Since the patient's brother has the condition but both her parents are asymptomatic, the parents must be carriers for this trait (heterozygous). Mendelian principles are used to calculate the patient's probability of being a heterozygous carrier. The Hardy-Weinberg principle is used to calculate the husband's probability of being a heterozygous carrier. Finally, the probability of the offspring having the condition (i.e., being homozygous) can be calculated with conditional probability rules.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of headache, nasal discharge, and dry cough. He has had no dyspnea, visual changes, or painful eye movements. He has not been going to work during this time because he has been sleeping poorly. Medical history is unremarkable and he takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 8 years. The patient is allergic to penicillin. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 126/82 mm Hg. Examination shows clear mucus in the nostrils and the posterior oropharynx. Pulmonary examination is shown. There are no focal neurologic findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhaled beclomethasone therapy is indicated for the maintenance treatment of asthma, which typically presents with a dry cough that affects sleep quality and is often associated with rhinorrhea. However, in asthma, rhinorrhea is usually due to chronic allergic rhinitis, and characteristic features of lower airway involvement (e.g., dyspnea and chest tightness, end-expiratory wheezes) would be expected. While inhaled beclomethasone has no benefit in patients with acute viral and bacterial rhinosinusitis, short-term application of topical, intranasal steroids (e.g., fluticasone, beclomethasone) may be indicated to reduce nasal symptoms and inflammation.

B) CORRECT:

The standard of care in acute viral rhinosinusitis is reassurance and close follow-up. Uncomplicated viral sinusitis is generally self-limiting, and supportive therapy with rest, hydration, antipyretics, and oral analgesics is sufficient. In addition, topical, intranasal steroids (e.g., fluticasone, beclomethasone), nasal saline lavage, and decongestive nose drops (e.g., oxymetazoline) can provide symptomatic relief. If bacterial rhinosinusitis or bacterial superinfection is suspected, antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin-clavulanate or, in this adult patient with penicillin allergy, with doxycycline, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin, is indicated for 5–10 days. Further imaging tests are generally not recommended unless a complication (e.g., orbital cellulitis) or a differential diagnosis (e.g., nasal polyps) is suspected.

C) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the sinuses is the imaging modality of choice in acute sinusitis. However, a CT scan is indicated only if symptoms fail to improve within 7 days of diagnosis or worsen during the initial management of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis, in the case of suspected complications (e.g., osteomyelitis, orbital cellulitis), or to rule out differential diagnoses (e.g., neoplasms). This patient has only had symptoms of acute viral rhinosinusitis for 4 days and does not have visual changes or painful eye movements that might suggest a complication. Performing a CT scan would only expose the patient to unnecessary radiation.
Image Description:

CT paranasal sinuses (coronal plane) of a patient with acute sinusitis

The right maxillary sinus (green overlay) is completely opacified. Extensive soft tissue density material (red overlay) is also present in the ipsilateral nasal cavity and the right ethmoid sinus is nearly completely opacified.

D) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is considered a second-line antibiotic for the treatment of acute bacterial sinusitis and may also be used in patients with penicillin allergy, like this patient. However, this patient has no characteristic features of a bacterial infection (i.e., severe symptoms initial ≥ 3 days, > 39°C fever, facial pain, purulent nasal discharge) or superinfection (i.e., persistent symptoms for ≥ 10 days without clinical improvement, initially improving and then worsening symptoms after 5–6 days). Therefore, antibiotics are not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Sputum gram stain and culture are indicated for the diagnostic workup of community-acquired pneumonia if symptoms are severe or persistent, or if the patient is hospitalized. This patient does not have features suggestive of typical pneumonia. While atypical pneumonia often manifests with headaches and dry cough, other constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue, myalgias) and dyspnea are usually present. Microbiological tests are not indicated for acute viral rhinosinusitis unless complications (e.g., orbital cellulitis, osteomyelitis) are suspected based on clinical presentation (e.g., visual changes, eye movements).

F) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin, with or without clavulanate, is considered the first-line treatment for acute bacterial rhinosinusitis. However, this patient has no characteristic features of a bacterial infection, (i.e., severe symptoms initial ≥ 3 days; > 39°C fever, facial pain, purulent nasal discharge) or superinfection (i.e., persistent symptoms for ≥ 10 days without clinical improvement, initially improving and then worsening symptoms after 5–6 days). Moreover, this patient has a history of penicillin allergy; amoxicillin-clavulanate should, therefore, be avoided.

G) INCORRECT:

A chest x-ray is commonly used to diagnose community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), which typically manifests with fever and cough. However, this patient has no other features suggestive of CAP (e.g., high fever, severe malaise, tachypnea, dyspnea, purulent sputum). Moreover, his pulmonary examination is normal; no crackles or rales are present. A chest x-ray is not required for the diagnosis of acute rhinosinusitis and would expose the patient to unnecessary radiation.
questions.hint: This patient's rhinorrhea, fever, headache, dry cough, duration of symptoms, and physical examination findings are consistent with acute viral rhinosinusitis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 2-week history of nonproductive cough and nasal discharge. She has had difficulty paying attention in class because the nasal discharge has become thicker and more purulent over the past 5 days. She also says, “my cheeks hurt and feel very full.” She has been taking over-the-counter oral decongestants without much relief. She is allergic to peanuts and pollen. She has no other personal or family history of serious illness and takes no other medications. Immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows congested nasal mucosa with purulent discharge from the nostrils bilaterally. There is mild swelling and tenderness to palpation over both maxillary sinuses. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A foreign body lodged in the nasal cavity can cause symptoms such as purulent nasal discharge, nasal congestion, and facial pain due to local inflammation and secondary infection (e.g., rhinosinusitis). However, in most cases, nasal discharge is unilateral and foul-smelling. Moreover, there is nothing in this patient's history to suggest that a foreign body was inserted.

B) INCORRECT:

An allergic reaction in the form of allergic rhinosinusitis can manifest with nasal congestion and facial pain, which are seen in this patient. However, further symptoms of allergy (e.g., sneezing, pruritus, conjunctivitis) would be expected. Moreover, the acute onset of fever and purulent nasal discharge in this patient do not suggest allergic rhinosinusitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Nasal polyps can manifest with bilateral nasal obstruction and may be a predisposing factor for acute rhinosinusitis, which this patient has. However, nasal polyps are not typically seen in children, and chronic (i.e., > 12 weeks) rather than acute rhinosinusitis is more common with nasal polyps. Furthermore, other characteristic findings of nasal polyps, such as postnasal drip and impaired olfactory function, are absent in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

The lack of improvement in this patient's symptoms over the course of 2 weeks suggests acute bacterial rhinosinusitis, which is typically caused by a secondary bacterial infection. Acute bacterial rhinosinusitis is most commonly a result of a recent viral upper respiratory tract infection (URTI). Viral URIs cause ostial obstruction and dysfunction of the mucociliary apparatus, which in turn promote the inoculation of bacteria and the development of sinusitis. The most common causative organisms of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis are S. pneumoniae, nontypeable H. influenzae, and M. catarrhalis. Diagnosis is usually clinical and first-line treatment consists of oral amoxicillin with or without clavulanate for 5–10 days.

Imaging or endoscopy should be considered if symptoms fail to improve within 7 days of diagnosis or worsen during the initial management of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis. CT scan of the sinuses is the imaging modality of choice.

E) INCORRECT:

An invasive fungal infection can be caused by fungi such as Aspergillus spp., Fusarium spp., and Mucorales spp., and can lead to acute rhinosinusitis, which this patient has. However, fungal rhinosinusitis most commonly develops in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., those with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, steroid use), which is not the case here. Furthermore, patients with an invasive fungal infection commonly present with acute, severe features (more common with Mucorales spp.) such as cranial nerve palsies, facial swelling, erythema, and proptosis, or with chronic sinusitis (i.e., symptoms lasting > 12 weeks).
questions.hint: This patient has a fever, facial pain, nasal congestion with bilateral purulent nasal discharge, and maxillary sinus tenderness that has persisted for ≥ 10 days without improvement.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 2-day history of worsening pain and swelling in the right eye. He has had fever, nasal congestion, and pain over the right cheek for the past 10 days that did not improve with over-the-counter medication. Three years ago, he was diagnosed with atopic dermatitis. There is no family history of serious illness. His only medication is topical hydrocortisone. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F). Ophthalmologic examination shows erythema, tenderness, and swelling of the right eyelid; there is mild conjunctival injection. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; extraocular muscles are intact and their movement is not painful. Examination of the left eye shows no abnormalities. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. There is purulent nasal discharge. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hordeolum commonly manifests with ocular pain. However, this condition is characterized by localized, tender, erythematous, pus-filled nodules at the distal lid margin. This patient's presentation with erythema and swelling of the entire eyelid is suggestive of a different condition.
Image Description:

Right eye

There is local nodular erythematous swelling of the medial part of the right lower eyelid.

This finding is consistent with an internal hordeolum (stye), an acute bacterial inflammation of a meibomian gland in the eyelid.

B) INCORRECT:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a life-threatening complication of bacterial rhinosinusitis that can manifest with erythema and swelling of the eyelid, ocular pain, and fever. However, more severe symptoms, such as headache, ophthalmoplegia, vision changes (e.g., diplopia, vision loss), signs of cranial nerve dysfunction (e.g., tinnitus, facial palsy), and seizures are expected in cavernous sinus thrombosis. This patient's presentation with normal visual acuity and intact extraocular muscles is suggestive of a different condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the orbital contents posterior to the orbital septum that can manifest with unilateral eyelid erythema and swelling, ocular pain, and fever, and is commonly preceded by bacterial rhinosinusitis. However, orbital cellulitis characteristically manifests with reduced vision, ophthalmoplegia, proptosis (due to inflammation of the intraorbital fat), and/or painful eye movement (due to inflammation of the extraocular muscles), none of which are seen here.
Image Description:

The left upper and lower eyelids are red and severely swollen, resulting in the patient not being able to open the eye. Orbital cellulitis is an emergency requiring immediate treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Orbital abscesses can occur as a complication of bacterial rhinosinusitis and manifest with fever, ocular pain, eyelid swelling, and erythema. However, in orbital abscesses, more severe symptoms of orbital involvement (e.g., ophthalmoplegia, reduced vision, and proptosis) would be expected. This patient's presentation with unlimited eye movement and normal visual acuity suggests a different condition.

E) CORRECT:

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the eyelid and periorbital soft tissues anterior to the orbital septum that does not involve the orbital contents (see “Orbital cellulitis vs. preseptal cellulitis” table). This condition is commonly preceded by upper respiratory tract infections such as bacterial rhinosinusitis, but it can also develop as a result of a contiguous local soft tissue infection (e.g., due to dacryocystitis, insect or animal bites, or local trauma). Typical manifestations include ocular pain and unilateral eyelid erythema and swelling; chemosis and fever are less commonly seen. While diagnosis is primarily clinical, a CT scan of the orbits and sinuses should be performed if there is evidence of orbital cellulitis, or if symptoms are severe (e.g., marked eyelid swelling, high fever, leukocytosis) or fail to regress under adequate therapy. Treatment consists of oral antibiotics with coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and close outpatient follow-up.
questions.hint: This patient has no symptoms that would suggest the involvement of extraocular muscles (e.g., reduced vision, ophthalmoplegia, or painful eye movement) or intraorbital fat tissue (e.g., proptosis).

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman reports that she has had recurrent pulmonary, ear, and sinus infections for as long as she can remember. She was told that her cultures have grown Pseudomonas aeruginosa. She and her husband have been trying unsuccessfully to conceive a child for the past year and a half.
CT of the chest is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic granulomatous disease is not associated with situs inversus.

B) INCORRECT:

Alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency is not associated with situs inversus.

C) INCORRECT:

Common variable immunodeficiency is not associated with situs inversus.

D) INCORRECT:

Cystic fibrosis can manifest with infertility, bronchiectasis, and sinopulmonary disease, but it is not associated with situs inversus.

E) CORRECT:

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a rare, autosomal recessive, heterogeneous group of disorders affecting the structure of the cilia; it manifests in childhood. The cilia beat more slowly than normal or beat with an abnormal pattern, impairing mucociliary clearance and causing chronic airways disease.

The main complications of PCD involve the upper respiratory tract (sinus infections, chronic otitis media with effusion, or hearing loss), lower respiratory tract (bronchiectasis), cardiovascular system (situs inversus), and reproductive system (infertility, subfertility, or recurrent ectopic pregnancies). About 50% of patients with PCD have Kartagener syndrome, which is characterized by the triad of sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (as shown in this patient’s CT scan).

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who presents with bronchiectasis, recurrent sinus infections, infertility, and situs inversus is primary ciliary dyskinesia.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia reports fever, chills, purulent nasal drainage, severe facial pain, and headache for the past 10 days. Two weeks ago, she saw her primary care provider for symptoms of fever, chills, malaise, sore throat, and a mild headache and was diagnosed with a viral syndrome.
On physical examination, her vital signs are normal with the exception of a temperature of 38.9°C. She has boggy nasal mucosa, marked facial tenderness, and mild erythema of the pharynx. Laboratory investigations, including a complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel, are within normal limits. She has no known drug allergies.
In addition to symptomatic therapy, which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875 mg by mouth twice daily for 5 to 7 days
Azithromycin 500 mg by mouth for one dose, followed by 250 mg by mouth once daily for 4 days
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 160/800 mg twice daily for 3 to 7 days
Levofloxacin 500 mg by mouth once daily for 5 to 7 days

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Fever, chills, purulent nasal drainage, facial pain, and headache suggest acute bacterial rhinosinusitis. The diagnosis should be suspected when a patient has persistent symptoms or signs for ≥ 10 days, when a patient has severe symptoms or signs for at least 3 to 4 days, or when a patient has worsening symptoms or signs following a typical upper respiratory infection that appeared to initially be improving (“double sickening”).

The treatment for immunocompetent patients with uncomplicated bacterial rhinosinusitis is amoxicillin-clavulanate 875 mg by mouth twice daily for 5 to 7 days. Amoxicillin-clavulanate is a combination agent containing amoxicillin and a beta-lactamase inhibitor. Although certain professional societies still recommend amoxicillin alone in this setting, the recommendation from the Infectious Diseases Society of America is to opt for amoxicillin-clavulanate. This is because beta-lactamase-producing organisms, such as Moraxella in children and Haemophilus influenzae in adults, are increasingly common pathogens in bacterial rhinosinusitis, However, there are no clinical trials proving the superiority of amoxicillin-clavulanate over amoxicillin alone.

Key learning point: The most appropriate antibiotic treatment for immunocompetent patients with uncomplicated bacterial rhinosinusitis and severe symptoms lasting ≥ 10 days is amoxicillin-clavulanate 875 mg by mouth twice daily for 5 to 7 days as initial therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

No antibiotic therapy is necessary if the patient is suspected to have viral rhinosinusitis. The presence of persistent symptoms for ≥10 days and worsening symptoms following a typical upper respiratory infection that appeared to initially be improving (“double sickening”) suggest bacterial rhinosinusitis, which requires antibiotic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is not an appropriate option for treating acute bacterial rhinosinusitis because of the high rates of resistance of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

D) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is not an appropriate option for treating acute bacterial rhinosinusitis because of the high rates of resistance of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

E) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is a second-line choice for bacterial rhinosinusitis in patients who have anaphylaxis or an allergy to penicillin or for whom amoxicillin-clavulanate does not work.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman with a 2-year history of asthma presents with chronic nasal congestion that began after an uncomplicated upper respiratory infection 3 months ago in which she tested negative for SARS-CoV-2. Since then, she has noted a loss of her senses of smell and taste, as well as an increase in asthma symptoms.
She works as a hair stylist and notes that exposure to hair spray in the salon worsens her nasal congestion. She does not smoke cigarettes.
On examination, she has severe nasal congestion but no purulent drainage. In her right naris, she appears to have a small nasal polyp.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Waters’ radiographic views of the sinuses

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radiographic examination of the sinuses, including a Waters’ view, does not provide sufficient detail to reveal the extent of disease or to identify the specific sinus components affected.

B) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin levels are appropriate to exclude common variable immunodeficiency in patients with recurrent sinopulmonary infections, especially if those infections develop without a preceding viral infection.

C) CORRECT:

The often-subtle clinical manifestations of chronic sinusitis include nasal congestion and loss of the sense of smell (and resulting reduction in the sense of taste). Compared with acute sinusitis, chronic sinusitis is more gradual in onset and is not associated with fever. Because the physical examination in chronic sinusitis may be normal and fail to reveal the extent of disease, CT of the sinuses is indicated in patients with this clinical presentation. This imaging will help rule out alternate diagnoses such as malignancy, determine the presence and extent of chronic rhinosinusitis, and show any nasal polyps. CT is especially important to establish a diagnosis for patients who have received multiple courses of antibiotics for presumed, but not documented, chronic sinusitis.

Key learning point: The most effective test to further evaluate for chronic sinusitis is CT of the sinuses.

D) INCORRECT:

Biopsy of the nasal polyp is rarely indicated and thus should not be considered in the initial evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

In the absence of signs and symptoms consistent with allergic rhinitis, allergy testing would not be the best next step in the evaluation. Asking this patient about sensitivity to aspirin and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is important because if these medications trigger her asthma, she likely has aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). Although NSAIDs should be avoided in these patients, aspirin desensitization should be considered because it has been shown to improve asthma and nasal polyposis in patients with AERD.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman reports 14 days of nasal congestion, facial pain, and purulent nasal drainage that has not improved with watchful waiting. She is currently afebrile and has tenderness over the sinuses. Given the lack of improvement, you decide to administer antibiotics.
Which one of the following antibiotics is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Respiratory fluoroquinolones, such as levofloxacin and moxifloxacin, are effective treatments for rhinosinusitis but have serious adverse effects and are therefore not considered first-line therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Given current resistance patterns, azithromycin is less effective at reducing symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Given current resistance patterns, cefdinir is less effective at reducing symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Given current resistance patterns, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is less effective at reducing symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

Rhinosinusitis is characterized by nasal congestion, facial pain, and nasal drainage. The vast majority of cases are viral in origin, with less than 2% complicated by bacterial infections. Most cases will resolve in 7 days with watchful waiting and conservative measures and will not require antibiotics. Indications for antimicrobial therapy for presumed acute bacterial rhinosinusitis include: (1) no signs of improvement after 7 to 10 days; (2) severe symptoms at onset or signs of fever (> 39°C) that last for more than 3 days; and (3) worsening of symptoms after an initial improvement.

Amoxicillin-clavulanate is the preferred empiric treatment for adults who are not allergic to penicillin. The dosing for most patients is 500 mg/125 mg by mouth three times daily or 875 mg/125 mg by mouth twice daily. Amoxicillin alone is sometimes used but may be less effective because of increasing resistance to amoxicillin among respiratory pathogens, such as Haemophilus influenzae.

Key learning point: The preferred first-line therapy for acute bacterial rhinosinusitis is amoxicillin-clavulanate.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman reports having facial discomfort and congestion for the past 10 days. Her medical history includes chronic nasal congestion and anosmia, which has worsened during the past few years. She is otherwise healthy, has no allergies, and is taking no medications.
On physical examination, her vital signs are normal, and she is afebrile. She has no tenderness to palpation over her sinuses. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals bilateral lobulated masses covered in pale mucosa in both nasal cavities.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics, such as amoxicillin, are not indicated in a patient without signs of infection.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan and subsequent biopsy should be considered only if the patient does not respond to intranasal glucocorticoids and continues to be symptomatic in the acute setting.

C) INCORRECT:

Allergy testing can sometimes be helpful in long-term care, but many nasal polyps are not allergic in origin.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan and subsequent biopsy should be considered only if the patient does not respond to intranasal glucocorticoids and continues to be symptomatic in the acute setting.

E) CORRECT:

Bilateral masses in the nasal cavity that are lobulated and covered in pale mucosa are nasal polyps, part of the syndrome of chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyposis. Nasal polyps can contribute to the development of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis. Nasal polyposis and chronic rhinosinusitis can also be associated with aspirin hypersensitivity in asthmatic patients.

The primary medical treatment for nasal polyps is topical intranasal glucocorticoids used twice daily. A short course of oral glucocorticoids can hasten the initial response but does not provide long-term relief.

Key learning point: The primary medical therapy for nasal polyposis is topical nasal glucocorticoids.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman reports a 6-month history of chronic nasal congestion, facial pressure, and a decreased sense of smell. Her congestion has persisted despite several courses of antibiotics. She has a history of asthma and is allergic to aspirin.
The patient’s vital signs are unremarkable, and her neurologic and ophthalmologic examinations are normal. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals pale, mucoid masses filling each nasal cavity, with no apparent mucopurulent discharge.
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for the long-term management of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral and intranasal antihistamines (such as azelastine) may be useful in treating underlying allergic rhinitis but are not the primary treatment in chronic rhinosinusitis. They are not effective in shrinking nasal polyps.

B) CORRECT:

Intranasal glucocorticoid sprays are the cornerstone of treatment for chronic rhinosinusitis with or without nasal polyps. They decrease mucosal swelling and shrink nasal polyps, allowing for better sinus drainage and ease of breathing. If medical management fails to provide adequate relief, endoscopic sinus surgery can be performed to reduce the polyp burden and increase access to affected mucosa for topical treatments. Surgery does not cure the underlying problem.

Key learning point: The most appropriate medical therapy for chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyposis is an intranasal glucocorticoid spray.

C) INCORRECT:

Intranasal oxymetazoline is appropriate only for short-term relief of acute nasal congestion. It is often used initially for an acute flare of symptoms so that the intranasal steroids can reach the target tissues.

D) INCORRECT:

An oral glucocorticoid can be used as an initial treatment with a short taper, but long-term use can confer severe side effects, and effectiveness is often temporary.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral and intranasal antihistamines (such as azelastine) may be useful in treating underlying allergic rhinitis but are not the primary treatment in chronic rhinosinusitis. They are not effective in shrinking nasal polyps.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man has a 3-year history of chronic nasal congestion, consisting of three to four episodes of sinusitis per year. He has just finished a course of amoxicillin for his most recent infection. His medical history is remarkable for reactive airway disease, with two trips to the emergency department for shortness of breath during the past 10 years. He has allergies to dust, tree pollen, and aspirin.
Nasal examination shows bilateral polyps obstructing both nares, with clear mucus.
What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Nasal irrigation with distilled water twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nasal irrigation with isotonic or hypertonic saline can provide relief to patients with acute or chronic rhinosinusitis by thinning mucosal films and increasing mucociliary activity. Distilled water or tap water should not be used for nasal irrigation.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgery to remove the polyps may be necessary if medical treatment is inadequate, but the benefit of surgery is often temporary because polyps regrow if the underlying etiology is not addressed.

C) CORRECT:

Recurrent sinusitis can be caused by a number of factors, such as nasal polyps, sinus ostea obstruction, and allergic rhinitis. These causes all share the same basic etiology — obstruction of normal nasal sinus drainage. Treatment aimed at reestablishing adequate sinus drainage is the key to successful long-term management.

The most effective treatment for patients whose recurrent rhinosinusitis is caused by nasal polyps is a glucocorticoid nasal spray to shrink the nasal polyps and open the sinuses.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for bilateral nasal polyps causing recurrent sinusitis is regular use of a glucocorticoid spray.

D) INCORRECT:

Antihistamines, such as loratadine, will not shrink the polyps.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics will not shrink the polyps.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old otherwise healthy woman presents with facial pain and pressure that has worsened during the past 14 days despite the use of acetaminophen and ibuprofen. She reports having thick, greenish rhinorrhea and posterior nasal drip with nasal congestion; she initially had a cough and sore throat for 5 to 6 days that have since resolved. She reports no vision changes, clinically significant headaches, or drug allergies, and she takes no medications.
On examination, her temperature is 39°C, her heart rate is 89 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 142/75 mm Hg, and her oxygen saturation is 99% while she is breathing ambient air. There is pressure and marked tenderness on palpation of the skin overlying her bilateral maxilla.
What is the most appropriate initial step in this patient’s care?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT of the paranasal sinuses is unnecessary in patients who meet the clinical diagnostic criteria for uncomplicated acute bacterial rhinosinusitis, unless an intracranial or orbital complication from the acute sinusitis is a concern or the patient has failed treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Analgesic agents, topical glucocorticoids (such as fluticasone), decongestants, and nasal saline irrigations may provide symptomatic relief in combination with antibiotic therapy but do not alone constitute first-line therapy for acute bacterial rhinosinusitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Cultures of samples from the nasal cavity do not correlate well with sinus samples and are thus not recommended for managing uncomplicated acute bacterial rhinosinusitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin does not adequately cover respiratory pathogens.

E) CORRECT:

Diagnosis of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis is based on the presence of nasal obstruction, purulent nasal drainage, and/or facial pain or pressure lasting for 10 days to 4 weeks. The most common bacterial causes are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis.

According to guidelines from the Infectious Diseases Society of America, the first-line antibiotic treatment for acute bacterial rhinosinusitis is amoxicillin-clavulanate, for coverage of beta-lactamase-producing H. influenza (in addition to coverage of S. pneumoniae and M. catarrhalis).

Doxycycline and respiratory fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin or moxifloxacin) are the preferred second-line agents for patients with beta-lactam allergy.

Key learning point: The first-line therapy for acute bacterial rhinosinusitis is amoxicillin-clavulanate because of its efficacy against the most common causes of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis (Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis).

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy with a personal history of eczema and a family history of asthma reports feeling moderately ill with 2 weeks of worsening nasal discharge, which has become thicker. He also complains of increasing cough. He developed fever (39.0°C) yesterday. He takes no medications and has no allergies. There are multiple sick contacts at school.
Which one of the following physical examination findings is consistent with the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pale nasal mucosa is a sign of allergic rhinitis. Although this patient has eczema and a family history of asthma, his symptoms are not consistent with allergic rhinitis. Fever is not a feature of allergic rhinitis, and upper respiratory symptoms (cough, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion) do not steadily worsen; rather, they wax and wane.

B) INCORRECT:

Gingival erythema is a symptom of dental infection; given the constellation of symptoms more suggestive of rhinosinusitis and the absence of history of oral pain or gingival tenderness, this diagnosis is unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Swelling of the one eye would suggest preseptal cellulitis or orbital cellulitis, which are unlikely in a patient without eye complaints.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's worsening cough, rhinorrhea, and fever suggest acute bacterial rhinosinusitis. This diagnosis is made when a child with an acute upper respiratory tract infection presents with persistent illness (nasal discharge, daytime cough, or both lasting more than 10 days without improvement), a worsening course (worsening or new onset of nasal discharge, daytime cough, or fever after initial improvement), or severe onset (concurrent fever and purulent nasal discharge for at least 3 consecutive days).

Physical examination findings in a patient with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis are often nonspecific, but about a third of patients have facial pain or tenderness, which can be unilateral or bilateral.

Key learning point: In a school-age child, the three physical examination findings that are most consistent with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis are facial tenderness over the maxillary sinuses, nasal congestion, and malodorous breath.

E) INCORRECT:

Neck stiffness or pain on flexion of the neck is a sign of meningitis, but that is an unlikely diagnosis in this patient. Meningitis is rarely a complication of sinusitis, and the presentation would be more acute with fever, signs of meningeal irritation (including headache, vomiting, and anorexia), and changes in mental status.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl presents with a 12-day history of cough, nasal congestion, yellow rhinorrhea, and intermittent fevers, now with right-sided facial pain. The symptoms had improved after the first few days but returned with worsening nasal discharge and congestion.
Her temperature is 38.1°C, her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, her blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, and her oxygen saturation is 99% when she breathes ambient air. She has nasal congestion and yellow mucoid rhinorrhea in both nares. Her heart sounds are normal. Transmitted upper airway sounds are heard throughout both lung fields without focal findings.
The patient is not allergic to any medications.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin monotherapy, although first-line for acute otitis media, does not have broad enough antibacterial coverage for acute sinusitis because it will not cover beta-lactamase-producing Moraxella catarrhalis or nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae, two common pathogens implicated in sinusitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Second- and third-generation cephalosporins, such as cefuroxime and cefdinir, are no longer recommended for empiric monotherapy in this setting because of increased rates of resistance to Streptococcus pneumoniae.

C) CORRECT:

This child's symptoms are consistent with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis, which can be diagnosed clinically if any one of the following criteria is present:

• Persistent symptoms, characterized by nasal discharge and daytime cough that last 10 days or more without improvement
• Worsening course, characterized by initial improvement in upper respiratory symptoms followed by a worsening or new onset of nasal discharge, cough, or fever
• Severe symptoms, such as fever ≥39°C and purulent nasal discharge or facial pain for 3 consecutive days

Acute bacterial rhinosinusitis, particularly in cases like this where the child is febrile and has prolonged symptoms (>10 days), is treated with a course of antibiotics. In children not allergic to penicillin, the recommended first-line therapy is amoxicillin-clavulanate.

Imaging studies, including radiography of the sinuses or contrast-enhanced CT of the paranasal sinuses, are unnecessary for this patient at this time, given that she meets the clinical criteria for rhinosinusitis. Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI would be appropriate if orbital or intracranial complications were suspected. Imaging may also be indicated if the clinical symptoms do not improve with antibiotic therapy.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for a child with uncomplicated acute bacterial rhinosinusitis is amoxicillin-clavulanate.

D) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is not recommended as first-line therapy for acute bacterial sinusitis. Levofloxacin is not recommended in the pediatric population except in the presence of severe bacterial resistance.

E) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is not recommended as first-line therapy for acute bacterial sinusitis. TMP-SMX is reserved for those not responsive to amoxicillin-clavulanate.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 7-year-old girl presents to the emergency department (ED) with headache, vomiting, and intermittent fevers. She has had a cough, persistent nasal congestion, and frontal headaches for 3 weeks. Her mother reports that the mucus from the congestion was initially clear but is now thick and yellow-green in color. This morning the girl woke up with a severe headache that has not been relieved by acetaminophen or ibuprofen. She also started vomiting today and has not been able to tolerate any solid food since yesterday. She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
She has a temperature of 39.4°C, a heart rate of 126 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 127/72 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 95% while she breathes ambient air. On examination, she is drowsy and has trouble following directions. Aside from tachycardia and tachypnea, her cardiovascular and pulmonary examinations are within normal limits. She is unable to cooperate with a complete neurologic examination but appears weaker on her right side than on her left. During the examination, she has a brief, self-resolving tonic-clonic seizure without any change in vital signs.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s diagnostic evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although MRI may be more sensitive than CT for cerebritis, satellite lesions, and brainstem lesions, it cannot usually be obtained as quickly or as easily as CT and is therefore not typically used in an emergency setting.

B) INCORRECT:

Contrast-enhanced CT of the brain, orbits, and sinuses should be performed immediately when focal findings are present in a patient with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis. The scan should be done before lumbar puncture to assess asymmetric edema and risk for brain herniation.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s signs and symptoms are consistent with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis that has extended into the central nervous system.

Acute bacterial rhinosinusitis is diagnosed clinically when a patient with an acute upper respiratory tract infection presents with persistent illness (nasal discharge, daytime cough, or both lasting >10 days without improvement), a worsening course (worsening or new onset of nasal discharge, daytime cough, or fever after initial improvement), or severe onset (concurrent fever and purulent nasal discharge for ≥3 consecutive days). If acute bacterial rhinosinusitis goes untreated, it can extend into the central nervous system and, in rare instances, cause brain abscess. Headache, altered mental status, vomiting, focal neurologic deficits, and seizures are all clinical signs that the infection may have spread from the sinuses to the parenchyma, leading to brain abscess. Brain abscess can also be caused by bacteremia, meningitis, or left-sided endocarditis.

Contrast-enhanced CT of the brain, orbits, and sinuses should be performed immediately when focal findings are present in a patient with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis. The scan should be done before lumbar puncture to assess asymmetric edema and risk for brain herniation.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first step in the diagnostic evaluation of a child with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis, new-onset focal neurologic findings, and a first-time seizure is CT of the brain, orbits, and sinuses.

D) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography is recommended for the evaluation of children with recurrent seizures, but this patient has no history of previous seizures, and her clinical findings are more consistent with extension of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis than with epilepsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Although sinus radiographs may reveal sinusitis, they are not an appropriate next step for this patient, as her neurologic findings (including altered mental status and right-sided weakness) indicate a deeper, neurologic infection.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy has a 2-day history of worsening pain and swelling in the right eye. He has had fever, nasal congestion, and pain over the right cheek for the past 10 days. Ophthalmologic examination shows erythema, tenderness, and swelling of the right eyelid; there is mild conjunctival injection. Extraocular muscles are intact and their movement is not painful. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. There is purulent nasal discharge. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hordeolum commonly manifests with ocular pain. However, this condition is characterized by localized, tender, erythematous, pus-filled nodules at the distal lid margin. This patient's presentation with erythema and swelling of the entire eyelid is suggestive of a different condition.
Image Description:

Right eye

There is local nodular erythematous swelling of the medial part of the right lower eyelid.

This finding is consistent with an internal hordeolum (stye), an acute bacterial inflammation of a meibomian gland in the eyelid.

B) INCORRECT:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a life-threatening complication of bacterial rhinosinusitis that can manifest with erythema and swelling of the eyelid, ocular pain, and fever. However, more severe symptoms, such as headache, ophthalmoplegia, vision changes (e.g., diplopia, vision loss), signs of cranial nerve dysfunction (e.g., tinnitus, facial palsy), and seizures are expected in cavernous sinus thrombosis. This patient's presentation with normal visual acuity and intact extraocular muscles is suggestive of a different condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the orbital contents posterior to the orbital septum that can manifest with unilateral eyelid erythema and swelling, ocular pain, and fever, and is commonly preceded by bacterial rhinosinusitis. However, orbital cellulitis characteristically manifests with reduced vision, ophthalmoplegia, proptosis (due to inflammation of the intraorbital fat), and/or painful eye movement (due to inflammation of the extraocular muscles), none of which are seen here.
Image Description:

The left upper and lower eyelids are red and severely swollen, resulting in the patient not being able to open the eye. Orbital cellulitis is an emergency requiring immediate treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Orbital abscesses can occur as a complication of bacterial rhinosinusitis and manifest with fever, ocular pain, eyelid swelling, and erythema. However, in orbital abscesses, more severe symptoms of orbital involvement (e.g., ophthalmoplegia, reduced vision, and proptosis) would be expected. This patient's presentation with unlimited eye movement and normal visual acuity suggests a different condition.

E) CORRECT:

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the eyelid and periorbital soft tissues anterior to the orbital septum that does not involve the orbital contents (see “Orbital cellulitis vs. preseptal cellulitis” table). This condition is commonly preceded by upper respiratory tract infections such as bacterial rhinosinusitis, but it can also develop as a result of a contiguous local soft tissue infection (e.g., due to dacryocystitis, insect or animal bites, or local trauma). Typical manifestations include ocular pain and unilateral eyelid erythema and swelling; chemosis and fever are less commonly seen. While diagnosis is primarily clinical, a CT scan of the orbits and sinuses should be performed if there is evidence of orbital cellulitis, or if symptoms are severe (e.g., marked eyelid swelling, high fever, leukocytosis) or fail to regress under adequate therapy. Treatment consists of oral antibiotics with coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and close outpatient follow-up.
questions.hint: This patient has no symptoms that would suggest the involvement of extraocular muscles (e.g., reduced vision, ophthalmoplegia, or painful eye movement) or intraorbital fat tissue (e.g., proptosis).

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of double vision and rapidly worsening pain and swelling of her right eye. For the past week, she has had nasal congestion, recurrent headaches, and a watery nasal discharge that became purulent 4 days ago. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Ophthalmic examination of the right eye shows proptosis and diffuse edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelids. Right eye movements are restricted and painful in all directions. There is tenderness to palpation over the right cheek and purulent nasal discharge in the right nasal cavity. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis. Which of the following provides the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics to this patient?

choices.text: Edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelid
Purulent nasal discharge and right cheek tenderness

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Unilateral diffuse edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelid can occur in any condition that causes ocular infection or inflammation, e.g. blepharitis, bacterial conjunctivitis, endophthalmitis, preseptal cellulitis, and orbital cellulitis. Therefore, diffuse inflammation of the eyelid as a sole clinical feature is non-specific and not an indication to initiate IV antibiotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Leukocytosis is a nonspecific symptom of many conditions, including viral infections or inflammatory conditions, some of which do not require antibiotic treatment at all. In this case, the patient's leukocytosis could be a sign of sinusitis or preseptal cellulitis. Bacterial sinusitis and mild preseptal cellulitis can be managed with oral antibiotics. Because both orbital cellulitis and preseptal cellulitis manifest with fever, leukocytosis, and acute ocular pain and inflammation, usually in conjunction with acute rhinosinusitis, it is important to identify specific findings of orbital cellulitis, which always requires IV antibiotics.

C) CORRECT:

Rapidly progressive pain with eye movements is a sign of inflammation of the orbital content. While fever, leukocytosis, and eyelid changes (e.g., edema, erythema, tenderness) can occur with both preseptal cellulitis and orbital cellulitis, painful ocular movements, ophthalmoplegia, reduced vision, and proptosis are specific for orbital cellulitis, a sight-threatening infection of the orbital contents. While preseptal cellulitis can be treated with oral antibiotics, the spread of infection to the orbital tissues requires prompt treatment with empiric IV antibiotics (vancomycin plus one of the following: ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, ampicillin/sulbactam, piperacillin/tazobactam).

See “Orbital cellulitis vs. preseptal cellulitis” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Purulent discharge in the right nasal cavity, right cheek tenderness, and a recent history of headaches and nasal congestion are characteristic of right maxillary sinusitis. Bacterial sinusitis is the most likely etiological factor of this patient's orbital cellulitis. However, oral (not parenteral) antibiotics alone would be appropriate to treat bacterial sinusitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Fever is a nonspecific symptom of many conditions, including viral infections or inflammatory conditions, some of which do not require antibiotic treatment at all. In this case, the patient's fever could be a sign of sinusitis or preseptal cellulitis. Bacterial sinusitis and mild preseptal cellulitis can be managed with oral antibiotics. Because both orbital cellulitis and preseptal cellulitis manifest with fever and acute ocular pain and inflammation, usually in conjunction with acute rhinosinusitis, it is important to identify specific findings of orbital cellulitis, which always requires IV antibiotics.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features consistent with right-sided orbital cellulitis. Her recent episode of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis (as evidenced by nasal congestion, headaches, cheek tenderness, and purulent nasal discharge) is the most likely primary source of infection.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy comes to the office because of a 2-week history of worsening nasal discharge and cough. He mentions the discharge has become thicker. He also developed a fever yesterday. He has a history of eczema. There are multiple sick contacts at his school. He has a family history of asthma. He takes no medications and has no allergies. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pale nasal mucosa is a sign of allergic rhinitis. Although this patient has eczema and a family history of asthma, his symptoms are not consistent with allergic rhinitis. Fever is not a feature of allergic rhinitis, and upper respiratory symptoms (cough, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion) do not steadily worsen; rather, they wax and wane.

B) INCORRECT:

Gingival erythema is a symptom of dental infection; given the constellation of symptoms more suggestive of rhinosinusitis and the absence of history of oral pain or gingival tenderness, this diagnosis is unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Swelling of the one eye would suggest preseptal cellulitis or orbital cellulitis, which are unlikely in a patient without eye complaints.

D) CORRECT:

Acute bacterial rhinosinusitis is diagnosed when a child with an acute upper respiratory tract infection presents with persistent illness (nasal discharge, daytime cough, or both lasting more than 10 days without improvement), a worsening course (worsening or new onset of nasal discharge, daytime cough, or fever after initial improvement), or severe onset (concurrent fever and purulent nasal discharge for at least 3 consecutive days).

Physical examination findings in a patient with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis are often nonspecific, but about a third of patients have facial pain or tenderness, which can be unilateral or bilateral.

Key learning point: In a school-age child, the three physical examination findings that are most consistent with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis are facial tenderness over the maxillary sinuses, nasal congestion, and malodorous breath.

E) INCORRECT:

Neck stiffness or pain on flexion of the neck is a sign of meningitis, but that is an unlikely diagnosis in this patient. Meningitis is rarely a complication of sinusitis, and the presentation would be more acute with fever, signs of meningeal irritation (including headache, vomiting, and anorexia), and changes in mental status.
questions.hint: This patient's worsening cough, rhinorrhea, and fever suggest acute bacterial rhinosinusitis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of severe pain and swelling of her right eye for 3 days. Over the past 2 weeks, she has had nasal congestion and a constant, mild headache. She did not visit a doctor and instead took over-the-counter naproxen and phenylephrine. Her nasal congestion has since improved, but the headache persists. She underwent a dental procedure for caries about 10 days ago. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F). Examination shows proptosis of the right eye. Vision is impaired in the affected eye. Her right upper and lower eyelids are erythematous, swollen, and tender to touch. Ocular movements cause severe pain. Her headache is worsened by leaning forward and improves when the patient is lying on her back. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis leads to proptosis and swelling of the conjunctiva.
